author: oaklandmatt
oaklandmatt
Slow Hand
content:
Sooooo.... It's come to my attention that not everyone has an internal monologue. A voice in their head. This is kind of wild to me. Supposedly as many as 50% of people don't have an inner monologue. 

It never occurred to me that people wouldn't, but I guess I shouldn't be surprised. My mind's eye is pretty lo-res, while some of my friends have the ability to visualize very detailed imagery in their heads.

Now I'm curious. Who here has an internal monologue and who does not?

Gimme a 👍 if you do have an internal monologue.
Gimme a 👎 if you don't have one.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes. Do all of it. Show your work, show your process, reach out to people, etc etc 

Spend some time doing ALL of it, and then figure out what rhythms and processes you feel authentic doing. Everything new always feels weird. But suffer though that and find some ways it works for you.

And think through it. You *could* send a bunch of DMs that say "hey you don't know me but listen to my work because I want to work with you." Probably send 100 and get a small percentage of those messages returns. Or maybe you should start by posting things you love and tagging the artists. Then if they respond say "man I'm such a big fan of XYZ song, the way you blah blah blah" and start things that way. No right or wrong ways. But just use the medium and see what you come up with.

It's SOCIAL media. If you treat it like "how can I promote myself," that might work. But if you treat it like a platform for interacting and sharing with people and artists and music you love, you'll probably have more success that way.

Also, it can be a dopamine time suck that eats away at your interactions with the physical world.

So you just gotta be intentional and see what your capacities are.

author: chrissorem
content:
Here is where we are at so far: O’Flaherty is known for his unorthodox and borderline mystical approach to mastering. While some engineers rely on meters, graphs, and measurable science, Ruairí prefers to keep things mysterious under the hood — very mysterious. No one really knows what’s going on in the session file… including Ruairí. And that’s the point.

Most of his day is spent clicking on vaguely psychedelic images of your waveform and nodding slowly. Sometimes he zooms in, sometimes he just stares at the phase scope like it owes him money. Occasionally, he’ll touch a knob — but never the same one twice.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Now imagine you keep going, slowly improving but over time you start paying more and more attention to your hands and not to the shadows they cast. You become enchanted with the clever contortions of your fingertips but stop really connecting with their effect in the world

This is what obsession with sound and tones can become. Mistaking the sounds we use to create feelings in our bodies, hearts and minds for an end goal unto themselves

So what does graduating look like? It doesn’t mean forgetting how to mic a kit or tune a vocal. It doesn’t necessarily  mean minimalism. It doesn’t really mean anything except focussing on what matters; how the sounds make you and hopefully your audience feel. This is the basis of my repeated hope for people to “Listen like a 15 year old girl”. She doesn’t care about sound, she cares how it makes her *feel* 

An argument for feel is often viewed as an argument *against* great sound or *for* “phoning it in” which of course makes no sense. Many things can sound AND feel great, as long as you keep your eyes on the shadow on the wall, and not on your fingers….

author: BatMeckley
content:
No. 
No no. 
No to the hell nah no. 
This is why I keep telling people how important it is to develop their taste. 
Alex shares similar sonic traits with his Dad because he grew up listening to someone go, “Christ there’s so much wooliness in this vocal, we need to get it up to where the audience can hear the words” or “let’s cut some space HERE in the track so that THIS sits”. The whole secret is the WHY, not the fact that he gifted him a MH Channel strip license. 

I’ve been really into photography lately, and I’m constantly struck by how my professional photographer little brother constantly gets better results than i do on worse gear. And it’s because he knows what to look for in a photograph, and then it’s easy enough to work backwards from there. That’s the skill of the whole thing. And it’s such a strong parallel to watching the Machine Head collectors on gearspace or the $12k PRS blues lawyers on TGP wax poetic about gear while clearly having no idea what the gear is actually used for. 

Focus on the right things.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The creator of the art will never see it as the audience sees it. Almost every artist I know would like to redo things that they've already put out in the world. There's endless stories of this phenomenon. And while we as creators and contributors try and perfect the things that we make, it's very often the imperfections and the personality of the moment that makes art unique and powerful.

Our art form is essentially about capturing moments/ time periods. Rarely do retrospective editing moves enhance that initial feeling imho

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok I'm gonna go in depth about this because I think it's FASCINATING.

The top three songs have an overlapping core fanbase that is largely unrepresented (or maligned) in popular culture: the white working class.

But none of them are really straightforward "country." 

The first song is a viral hit that seemingly comes from an authentic Appalachian kid talking about class. Despite his very explicit statements about hating political division, it has of course been wildly politicized because everything on the internet is these days.

The second song is a white male country singer covering a black lesbian female's iconic song ALSO about class. Talk about intersectionality...

The third song is the longest running solo male #1 song on the Hot 100 from the biggest star in country music (and really one of the biggest stars in the world... just, again, not covered by the current fashion of mainstream culture). It's a kinda-country-but-kinda-just-pop song co-written by the biggest country writer in history (Ashley Gorley) as well as once-rapper-and-Dr-luke-protege J Kash.

The rest of the chart is interesting too. #4 is a four year old taylor swift song that has gained traction online from her current tour so the label started pushing it as a single. 

There are two Olivia Rodrigo songs, signaling a true new superstar.

There are two songs from the Barbie soundtrack. In a "dying" movie industry currently on strike, when is the last time two songs from a movie soundtrack have been in the top 10? I dunno.

And lastly, there's only 1 trap song. The majority of these songs are people playing real instruments and writing more "classic" singer-songwriter songs. Rap music is really having a lull after a decade of dominance.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Story time. Last night me and my gf saw Janelle Monáe on her age of pleasure tour at the Ryman here in Nashville. While she was making her entrance on stage something weird happened to the sound. Loud pop, clicking, and then no signal, but seemed like the in-ears / on stage monitoring were still working. Her and the band played through the entire first song while everyone in the audience was just looking around confused. Many heads turning to the sound board. Eventually the crowd started a 'we can't hear you' chant and Janelle and the band realized what was going on. They all calmly walked off stage. Took maybe ten minutes for it all to get sorted with the sound. Then Janelle and her band proceeded to come back out redo the entire intro / first song and give maybe the greatest live performance I've ever witnessed. The show ended with a double encore. It felt like such an amazing example of class and professionalism. I got the sense that she decided, after walking off the stage the first time, that not a single person in the audience will remember this show being anything but amazing and it was. Truly undeniable. If anyone here has a chance to catch any of the remaining shows on her tour, I could not recommend it enough. 🤘

author: LAPhill
content:
This feels like a good time to remind everyone to be careful about how much they share of their personal life on social media. I had a stalker that was a fan of a game I scored (surprisingly, the least-known thing I've ever done) start wishing my now-wife happy birthday on IG (she doesn't publicize her birthday and I would very rarely have her in posts). Then he made characters of us on his Wii. I eventually thought I had the situation cooled down, until he tagged us both, congratulating us on our engagement and knew when and where our wedding was, suggesting he might crash it.

I make a point of keeping my family out of any posts now, and don't show pictures of the area where I live, etc. etc..

author: tim adamson 🇦🇺
content:
I wanted to make a similar heartfelt post. I've been super under the pump the past few months with corporate AV work and had a last minute session yesterday that went really well and everyone's super happy with! 

This was only the second session I've done in this studio, the first was a semi nightmare which lay beyond my control (I had two hours to setup from scratch and record 4 tracks with a trio in a brand new room.. and I'm no Noah Needleman) although everyone's happy with it, it was somewhat disheartening to have my first session back in the studio be completely rushed and slapped together 

This time I really wanted to prepare and took to digging in the server for a game plan. Shout outs to @chrissorem and @Eric Martin, I picked up 2 x m88s for vocal and double bass.... I'm super impressed and stoked with how these sound and I wouldn't have found them without your suggestions. (I also got a great deal on a M130, I haven't heard many people talk about them but it ruled on overhead)

But mainly, as someone who's not recording everyday, after a pretty average session a few weeks back, just reading this servers helped really refresh my perspective on why I'm doing what I'm doing and to go into the next session better prepared and focused. Very nice to have great feeling tracks right after and pretty average session in a new space

Big thanks to everyone!!

author: BatMeckley
content:
I have found myself avoiding working with certain people that are (in my humble opinion, everyone’s got their own limits) too HypeBeast on social media. 

I don’t want someone who’s posting 38 videos in the studio talking in to the camera “In the lab with Beckley. Cooking up some 🔥! <air horn sounds>”. There’s a certain line in social media where it goes from “I’m so stoked to be doing this cool thing” to “I’m doing this cool thing and you’re NOT” that matters to me. Also, the people that are more concerned with telling people about what they’re doing than the actual doing of it.

Long story long, social media is useful to me to weed out the people I don’t want to work with as much as it helps find people I do.

author: Slow Hand
content:
---

At the end of the day I suppose I'm motivated to make music because what I want is not being represented anywhere else or I feel that I have something worth saying. I'm not aiming to be contrarian, but I want to follow the song and see where it leads me. I want to be surprised. Very often that runs counter to conventional wisdom around writing songs in "a way that people actually like."

Sometimes I feel as if I'm out here in the woods building a tiny little cathedral just for myself and a small group of people who stumbled upon it. If they wander in I'll serve them a nice meal and then send them on their way.

That said, I also don't have any expectation that I deserve to find success. I'm not going to get grumpy when my art doesn't pay off for me. I've got no illusions there. If somebody wants to make money in music they shouldn't be surprised when their Appalachian EDM doo-wop opera fails to find an audience. But if they make it I'd sure love to hear it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
On reflection, the material benefits of *Option #1* are a nice selling point, but I think the bigger opportunity is to harness the superpower of rendering hit music at will. It would give me tremendous sway over the music industry once everyone comes to recognize that I can't miss. I would leverage that influence to make some positive changes where I can. Set up some institutions to cultivate and nurture the next generation of artists. 

Presumably, while the hit music I’m making runs counter to my personal tastes, it seems reasonable that it would still be valuable to *someone*. Just not to me. That will be my curse. I would dutifully churn out hits as fast as I am able to and gift humanity with a tsunami of unimpeachable pop awesomeness that will endure for a century. My sacrifice would be everyone else’s gain.

Counter-intuitively, by saturating the market with my personal brand of songwriting it would inspire the next generation of songwriters. Unable to compete with my torrent of sure-shot pop badness they would respond by writing new music that is the direct antithesis of my own brand of hits. With a little luck, the musical output of these writers would be exactly what I wished to hear all along.

That’s a win/win right there. I just have to suffer a bit. I choose *Option #1*.

author: cian riordan
content: I remember the first day I flew down to interview with Eric V. We were gonna just spend the weekend in the studio together and make sure the vibe was right... turns out I got roped into one of his rounds of speaker moving fuckery. The speakers were his giant UREI 813c's on top of these custom subs... very heavy... and only sitting on cinder blocks. He was deep down a Fuzzmeasure rabbit hole and we were just moving, shooting, moving, shooting, moving back, shooting, etc, etc. When we'd finally make a change to the speaker position that seemed listenable, that was always the first song he would play to hear the speakers, followed by Back in Black. It's one of those few songs that's just cemented in my brain from hearing it so much -- like when you leave an image on a TV screen and it burns in -- that's that song in my ears.

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You might be right. There's quite a bit of unknowns though. The content flood of the last few years/ decade has not made as much catalog music as there used to be. So in that way, pre-internet pop culture is undervalued. We see this with iconic brands and reboots dominating Hollywood, non-hip hop samples and interpolations taking a bigger slice of pop music. 

Rod sold pub, records, and likeness. Irving Azoff has not made a lot of bad decions, historically. I also wouldn't be so confident in making calculations based on a few press release numbers. Catalog deals of this kind are incredibly complicated and have so much nuance. Like, does a $1mil record deal mean something? Yeah, but to make any judgement about it, you'd need a lot more detail. Catalog deals are much more complicated than a record deal.

Like I said, you might be right. But many good counterpoints too. Very interesting times. I definitely enjoyed reading your thoughts.

author: BatMeckley
content:
In all this, i think it’s important to not conflate “new” with “good” or even “better”. Those kind of classifications are best done with a wider lens. 

So often i see an artist shelf the better song for the newer song because it feels fresh to them.

Also important for us to remember that a lot of the classics that we think of as old were the absolute bleeding edge tech of their time (MJ, Hendrix, Dylan, Beatles). Things can be new and exciting and genre pushing and be awesome. But I still think it’s the song underneath that has to work and move people. I have many friends that are absolutely crushing with what I consider TikTok artists that are doing incredibly well with 15 second clips that I have a hard time believing will matter in 6 months let alone 6 years.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Sure. I pulled this from the article I was reading:

"Building 20 became a strange, chaotic domain, full of groups who had been thrown together by chance and who knew little about one another’s work. And yet, by the time it was finally demolished, in 1998, Building 20 had become a legend of innovation, widely regarded as one of the most creative spaces in the world. In the postwar decades, scientists working there pioneered a stunning list of breakthroughs, from advances in high-speed photography to the development of the physics behind microwaves. Building 20 served as an incubator for the Bose Corporation. It gave rise to the first video game and to Chomskyan linguistics. Stewart Brand, in his study “How Buildings Learn,” cites Building 20 as an example of a “Low Road” structure, a type of space that is unusually creative because it is so unwanted and underdesigned. (Another example is the Silicon Valley garage.) As a result, scientists in Building 20 felt free to remake their rooms, customizing the structure to fit their needs. Walls were torn down without permission; equipment was stored in the courtyards and bolted to the roof. When Jerrold Zacharias was developing the first atomic clock, working in Building 20, he removed two floors in his lab to make room for a three-story metal cylinder."

- Re-route to a different landing/home page
- Hide the comments section
- Hide suggested videos in the sidebar

author: Adam Thein
content:
Ultimately follow your gut - only you know what's right for you.

But I wanted to say for @cian riordan to mix a track for you I feel like you guys must have something good musically going there.  In my experience a big part of true collaboration is having to let go of some control of some parts of the whole thing.  Just putting out there you might be walking away from something really cool in the early stages because of a desire to control every aspect of the project.  It sounds like there are a lot of people that care a lot about the project to invest their time and energy and taste into it.

Again - you know everything you are feeling and the dynamics and if it's not worth it to you then absolutely walk away.  But maybe worth it to try and make the best of it for another few months and see where it leads?  If you are worried about how other people perceive the marketing/instagram can't you just explain you don't have anything to do with that end of the project?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
From the 2021 article they link

- establish a solid goal hierarchy
- favor approach goals over avoidance goals
- utilize flexible restraint rather than rigid restraint, 
- adopt a process-focused approach rather than an outcome-focused approach, 
- favor mastery goals over performance goals,
- set ambitious goals with a little bit of slack, 
- lean on helpful implementation intention strategies, 
- and modify your environment to promote social support and enable periodic reminders and feedback while facilitating goal-compatible habit formation

Laying out the above as they suggest in the article you linked would def be a good way to ensure the various goals are consonant with one another. I’ll give it a whirl.

author: Slow Hand
content:
American patriotism takes a lot of different forms. There is a certain amount of pride about the country that I find to well-earned and genuinely proud about. But depending on your social circles you're just as likely to find some people who take it way too far, and that's something that leaves a bad taste in my mouth. It gets pretty chauvinistic.

Patriotic rhetoric ends up being a lever used by politicians and adjacent political influencers to rally people to their causes (no surprise there), but lately it's mutated into a particularly ugly form and now there's a stark divide between people who have been radicalized towards extreme political positions and those who would reject them. One group unite under this brand of souped-up patriotism and the other tends to reject patriotic displays entirely because it resembles the first group.

No doubt you can find this behavior in lots of places around the world, but America's been feeling extremely polarized lately and overt national pride ends up being a symbol that's been co-opted by one group. So people here can be squeamish about it.

You'll likely be fine if you want to fly your American flag proudly. I don't want to dissuade you. Only highlight a little of our cultural baggage around that topic.

Man, this is a huge topic. And would be hard to address without touching on the political. My lunch break is over but again my intuition is to ask why this might be the case and I think a few factors might contribute 

- older generations grew up in a “keep your head down” world, whereas younger grew up with a more social “if you see something say something” atmosphere. Ostensibly a good thing …

author: Pio
content:
One thing I’ve liked about entering into the world of music, during the last decade, has been that social media has kind of made the world… bigger for me?

I love my local scene in Dublin and in Ireland. I’m proud of what we can do, what a lot of fantastic artists of all different kinds are doing from here. At the same time, I see the possibility of complacency, and how quick we are to presume that the lack of opportunities we perceive are due to how tough the industry is… rather than the other possibility. When I look on social media, the pure talent and skill on display across the world can be crippling to see, if you look at it through a kind of despair-ready lens. But I’ve found that it can actually be really powerful in a positive way too - i feel its challenged me to work to become better at my craft. To seek to perform not at a local level, but as a part of a global scene, and I feel that’s been really healthy for me.

author: LAPhill
content:
My 2 cents: I was having dinner with some composers recently and one of mentioned feeding his online presence into Gemini or Chat GPT to get a sort of neutral assessment of how he's coming across. The idea is to make sure when people do look you up, they're getting the right idea (updated credits, good visibility on your biggest work, and the kind of vibe you want to give off).

I'm sure if you reach out to enough people, you'll get a few bites, it's a numbers game and a crapshoot. But these days, our first impression is often from our IG, so even if you don't want to be too active on social media, it's still worth making sure that for the people that do use it a lot, that you're leaving a strong one.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Jeremy Klein  yeah its definitely building toward passive income. even a big big hit will mean a sizable few checks and then a looong tail of smaller ones. 

real world example: i co-wrote, produced and mixed this song "fine by me" by andy grammer. i have four points on the master (3 as producer, 1 as mixer). the song was a decent sized Hot AC hit back in like 2012, and has gone double platinum since then. this is partially because the song did decently well as a single at radio, and partially because he has continued to have follow up hits and continues to tour. his fans still stream his older music. 

the first few royalty checks (starting in like 2014), were low five figures twice a year (again, that's from a *four* point royalty). now it's probably a couple thousand a year (like 1k, twice a year).

this is, again, a double platinum song from 10 years ago, from an artist that has a loyal fanbase. the song actually didn't go double platinum until 5 years after it came out (continued streaming).

author: BatMeckley
content: Yeah I played one of their 335’s that just had the most absurdly good fretwork I’ve ever seen. I think theoretically one of the things you’re supposed to get with the more expensive brands is a consistency… anyone can make a one off great. One of my best strats is a made in Mexico cheapy, but I had to literally play all 14 the store had and one was clearly better. I’ve had new Taylors shipped out on the road to me and they’ve always been sea worthy right out of the box. None have ever been quite as magic as my old man’s mahogany Martin, but none have been as awful as my Martin. That’s kinda what I meant by the prs comparison. You can order one sight unseen and I can almost guarantee it’ll do what it’s supposed to do. Almost never a 10, but never a 6 either. Always right around 7-9 if that makes any sense.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Couple things from my perspective. 
1) it’s our job as producers to make the artist’s vision a winner. If we haven’t done that, we’ve failed. Like when the artist asked for a wetter vocal, we don’t just crank the verb right? We make sure it’s not causing problems mucking up transients etc. same with instrumentation and all. 
2) it’s the artist we’re serving. So when we’re done and have gotten paid, they’re the ones who have to go out and tour it, promote it, share it with they’re moms and kids and SOs etc. They need to be happy with it. 
3) if we can’t make 1 happen, we make 2 happen and move on to the next one. 

Generally I find the more I’m able to serve the artist’s vision, over time the trust grows and they become more interested and even reliant on consensus. But there are always outliers songs and outlier clients and outlier collaborators and outlier artists. 

In the long run, ain’t we all just tryna get it right?

author: Zack Hames
Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Everything tells a story. For me, I love that before the digital age people were working toward precise time keeping. Entire towns in Switzerland were dedicated to it, like when the railway was built and bypassed this little town of Waldenburg. They ended up making the first chronographs for the Swiss Airforce in 1916! 

The care for the artistry and precision and aesthetics and how they all marry… I want that to be part of my story ya know?

Like Eric & his Japanese denim, or David & his coffee, those things help tell stories about who they are as people and how they move about the world. For lack of a better term, it’s a part of their brand. 

For you… well it seems like watches are very much a part of your history, but does it need to be a part of the story you’re trying to tell right now? Only you know that, and you shouldn’t feel bad for not giving a shit about it.

My theory is that the biggest negative impact was caused by label execs trying to monetize the platform and doing a poor job of it. Making “viral” really the only barrier for entry, and trying to view things made off that platform as only viable if it would work ON it. 

In truth I think some real artists have come from TikTok, and some of the trends, like the drop (not new I know,) and the 30 second edit, are great tools for songwriting.

author: Slow Hand
content:
What's cool about these tools is that I (who am not a painter) could probably mock up this same concept using AI images and some Photoshop collaging. I'd still have to have the idea and intention to realize it, but the bar for participation is far far lower. That's exciting.

My work will still probably lack a certain refinement because I'm a dilettante and haven't dedicated my life to the pursuit like a serious painter might, but there's so much human creativity waiting to explode once people learn to accept and harness these tools.

author: Slow Hand
content:
These tools are magic, but they're not a miracle. It still requires work and understanding. It's just a different kind of work than we're used to doing. We shouldn't expect it read our mind and generate something amazing. It's still a computer.

This is something that Jon Castelli has touched as one of his unspoken services and something that we all do. Because of Jon's depth and breadth of musical understanding he's able to interpret prompts given to him by his clients and interpret their abstract requests with a well-realized result that hits the mark. That's a pro service that AI's still can't cover. They can't bring deep contextual understanding and interpret meaning.

As a client, if I hire an illustrator to commission a specific image I'm not just hiring them for their technical ability to render images. The best illustrators are going to have a broad and deep awareness of all styles, modes of presentation, and compositional techniques. They're going to use all of their experience and knowledge to interpret what my needs are and deliver on that. That's not a trivial thing to do. AI's are getting closer, but they're not mind readers.

Even the best contractors have to deal with clients who don't know how to ask for what they want; the "I'll know it when I see it" type of client. In the case of these AI tools we're the "client" who need to learn how to ask for what we want.

author: austenballard
content:
> There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

I want to add to what Ruairí and Matt B said with another perspective. I've had the privilege of working in some very professional settings, where everyone needs to fade into the background to do their jobs properly, and that's absolutely the case at higher levels. And it makes things work. And everyone's cool about it.

But much of my work has been as producer, assistant producer or project manager/fixer for people working at decidedly lower levels. 

And idk how it is in other countries, but we have a glut of people here in the US who have a certificate from a for-profit recording school that says they know what they're doing, who think they're *the shit* for being in the room with some viral star off YouTube/Instagram/TikTok. But don't know how to use a damn patch bay. 

And when you're on the come up, especially as a writer or producer, you interact with a lot of these people, and you get REALLY sick of them REALLY fast. So that might be the source of some of the condescension you see. It's hard not to get jaded when you have to wade through so much incompetence. I feel like a bitter old man just typing this paragraph tbh but I hope I'm not the only one with this experience.

author: austenballard
content: I don't really know where to dig deeper though - or maybe a better way to put it is I don't know who's doing a good job of digging deep and curating these days. I feel like a lot of the weird and wonderful stuff from places that aren't LA, NYC, Nashville, Atlanta, London, Berlin, Toronto, etc. is obscured by material that might be more digestible to a mainstream pop audience but also seems like it's playing its heritage for diversity points rather than embodying authenticity

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@Nomograph Mastering I actually had this same rabbit hole in my brain a few years ago, but it was watches not cars for me. 

While Rolex is an example of manipulated rarity, there are watch brands that ride this line, and honestly I think it’s a really close analog for what you do Rauirí. Guys like RW Smith make 10 watches a year, by hand, the quality is exquisite and they are EXPENSIVE. It scales up from there,  but I think there’s someone in that lane that probably hits all the markers you want to. 

Mastering is a necessity, but you can drive your moms Carolla or buy yourself a cybertruck etc…

You can use your phone to tell time, but where is the joy or passion for the art?

Seiko’s Spring Drive comes to mind. Using technology to  improve the art of timekeeping rather just trying to perfect it. 

Idk there’s obviously a breakdown in that watches are either good at telling time or not… but the how is fascinating to me.

author: spectrummasters
content:
.....agreed. Im not shooting down his message. I would only have reservations around his weighting of the 40% is creation, 60% is world-building for garnering attention. Is this sustainable long term for musicians? Can you balance that much time given to your art and then even more to finding your audience?  Its an open question in my mind, partly born from having seen how musicians and djs in my community in London have quietly built lifelong careers in UKG and Drum n Bass on the back of pure devotion to their crafts and not so much pouring even more effort into self promotion. 
Its an alternative approach imho, that has now delivered a good few of them to a balanced, apparently affluent lifestyle in their 50s. Balanced as in, found the time to have children and build a private life with family as well as pursue a music career. And still going hard on the music , same as they always did.
Will Teddy Swims be burnt out at 50? Will he still love making music? 
There are quicker (and legal) ways to make money that enable us to be just as creative Giving  100% of your time to anything just to have a chance at the slim odds of making a living seems unwise imho.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
My partner and I will drive around and go on walks in new neighborhoods we've yet to explore in Nashville. A little snoopy but we enjoy viewing other houses—the architecture, landscaping, different land plots and how they feel. That's the most wandering I'm doing lately outside of when I get to travel.

I was just reading about "Building 20" at MIT. How its unconventional and chaotic design and autonomy afforded to occupants for self organization led to it becoming a wildly creative space and a sort of nexus of innovation. It encouraged wandering because it was such a maze and you couldn't help but bump into somebody unexpectedly. Picked up a copy of "How Buildings Learn" by Stewart Brand I'm excited to read. Fun to day dream about what a similar creative space for music or other artist modalities could be.

author: Slow Hand
content:
What you describe feels like what I think of as "conceptual alignment". When the essence of the song is fully realized because all elements are working in harmony (or sometimes appropriately discordant).

On those records the underlying emotion and message are expressed when the chords, melody, lyrics, sonics, and performance are all working in service of that thing. Every element is pushing in the same direction. They feel aligned.

Like a classical painting in which you can *feel* a strong emotion immediately because the composition, expression of the figures, color choice, and flow of movement in the image are all "pointing" at the underlying essence.

Does that sound at all like what you're experiencing?

author: Josh
content:
I mean, yes and no. 

It’s not about if it’s just good or bad. 

It’s about if it matches with the audience. 

There are great songs that can’t make it on the radio. There are great songs that can’t be played live because they don’t translate with the audiences energy. They still aren’t bad songs. Their intent is just different. 

I think you’re mistaking the idea of “bad” for “wrong”. 

There aren’t bad songs. There’s just wrong songs. Not every choice made during writing/production/mixing is going to resonate with everyone.

author: skinnybreakfast
content:
Sorry for the book incoming. But this is plaguing my mind. Has there been an in-depth discussion on live or in discord yet about musicians on tiktok? 

It's a crazy scene of selling your creative soul for 1 minute of attempting to go viral. and then if you do get a popular video, whatever that one was - that is now your thing... singing into a trash can doing RHCP covers... ok, now do another 100 of those.  I see so much talent on there, genuine talent and artists who have worked hard on their craft getting 10 views due to the algo... once the algo has tried your vid on a few people and it didn't stick the vid is dead... so it's totally hit and miss based on your first small sample of viewers.

I see this having a huge impact in many ways. On the plus - you are getting exposure to incredible new ideas, skills, trends, methods for being creative... on the negative it's demotivating to the nth degree, and cheapening the creative process, in my opinion.

Matt and Jon recently talked about track lengths getting shorter and shorter, now 2 minutes is the normal. Partly due to the attention span of people... well what is this going to do... 1 minute pop tracks incoming? Just gimme the hook in 30 seconds and let's move on please. :p. How can we get young people to lay on the floor and listen to 10 minute vinyl tracks again? In my opinion humanity NEEDS this :)) 

I also swear I've heard the influence of trending memes from tiktok coming through in music in the charts, but cannot really back this up.

What's everyone else's thoughts? I have a friend in LA who says everyone has gone crazy there for tiktok fame? 😛

author: Slow Hand
content: The Fiery Furnaces did a really neat live album a decade ago where they spliced together all of their live performances into a full album. Now many bands do that already, but they combined multiple takes for each *song.*  They'd take the chorus from Night 1 and splice it onto the second verse of night 4 and then do the outro from Night 7. The cool part was that the recordings, rooms, and audience are drastically different, so you end up with lots of cool sonic shifts on the downbeats of each section in the songs.

author: Slow Hand
content:
When did Spotify start defaulting to the "clean" version of tracks? I'm listening to this Baby Keem/Kendrick track right now and it's ruining it for me.

I recently re-listened to 'Blacks Reconstruction' by The Roots and it's completely unlistenable now that it has a good 80 edits in it, despite being labeled as the "Album Version": https://open.spotify.com/track/6cq1D3ZaL8SrrHkgHB8nwl?si=6720c9125a9e40b8

It's not as if records like this ever stood a chance of pop appeal and required an edited version to reach an audience. It's so dense with profanity that it'll never be played in public anyway. Now because of this censorship not only does it fail at being acceptable to a broad audience it's also rendered unlistenable to it's intended mature audience.

If I didn't already love this record and didn't already own an uncensored copy I almost certainly would never give it a fair listen and come to appreciate it. I can't help but wonder if a lot of great music today is being rejected out of hand and not discovered by new listeners because of the censorship.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Partly in light of recent Facebook… developments:

I would *very* happily leave Instagram—or make a private account and unfollow everyone except my actual friends—if I wasn’t worried that it would impact my work. I feel like I have anecdotal experience that, when I post more on Instagram, I work more. And so I keep at it even though Facebook/Instagram just generally bum me out—and are ruining society.*

I am a freelance engineer/mixer/etc. and rely almost completely on work for hire gigs, i.e. I’ve got basically no passive royalties coming in. I’ve gradually, recently gotten my name on a few bigger projects but by no means do I have random people hitting me up to work—the vast majority of my income comes from friends/acquaintances hiring me for their self-funded projects.

Has anyone else in a similar situation tried fully cutting the cord?

*BTW, this community is so rad, and I’m well aware it sprung out of Instagram. Life is complicated. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Zack Hames
content:
I didn't post on instagram from 2016 - 2021, then I started actively posting again, *strictly* about audio, music, engineering, projects. I have easily gotten 10+ projects this year from doing this. It's not all my work but it's been shockingly useful. THAT SAID, it is almost entirely from people I already knew, or friends of friends. You know this, but it's an effective way to keep YOU in people's front of mind for picking someone for a job, at least for independent projects.That's what it came down to. "Oh yeah, they are an engineer, I'll hit them up". A lot of work has been fully completed THROUGH the instagram DM's. It's genuinely insane to me but it's worked.

I think social media can and will be what you make of it. It's easy to be addicted (I definitely struggle with this) but 90% of what I am reading, ingesting, etc is all audio based. Lots of people post political stuff, news, or personal stuff and I can't entirely avoid it but for the most part I do compared to what I realize other people's feeds consist of.

I think instagram has worked for me, but it certainly won't make or break your career if you don't do good work in the first place. If you currently have 0 clients, it probably won't get you more clients. I legit think I have 300 followers which is embarrassingly low. My account is private. it still has worked for me, at this juncture in my career. I also have enjoyed the community aspect of engineers on insta and discord. 

Every interaction or project can lead to something new. That's why for a lot of people, saying "yes" to everything is the best at the beginning until you are doing so much that you have the freedom to say no.  thanks for coming to my Ted-X talk.

author: ALXCPH
content:
A concept i find really cool atm is fake bass notes using sub harmonics. 
Its basically the overtone Series but in the opposite direction.  Fx. If you take a bass note, lets say C. And u add in a low G under it, it Will produce a C the octave below that you Will be able to hear and feel. 
Its cool to use on piano or guitar when you want super low notes, but havent found many other use cases for it. 
I know alot of classical bass singers and beatboxers use it to reach those super crazy low notes(some of the sea shanty on tiktok as example). They’ll sing a normall bass C and then do a slight vocal fry which for some reason our body vibrates a fifth below the note you sing and it produces a note an octave below that you can hear and feel in your chest, without having to sing super low. 


I cant help but feel there must be some Way to use that concept in a mix to get some crazy subbass with out blowing out your headroom. Just haven figured it out yet!

author: LAPhill
content:
Given the exponential levels in advancements we're already seeing in AI, I think anyone who thinks what we do can't be replicated in a few short years might be fooling themselves. But the thing that can't be replicated is the audience's connection, right? 

Growing up, when there was music I liked, I latched onto everything I could about the artist. I digested as much as I could about who these people were, what they looked like, what they wore, what guitar they played, etc. etc.. Audiences are still going to seek a connection with other people, it's human nature. I don't think we can ever replace that connection with an AI. Until falling in love with robots becomes normalized, and then we have bigger problems.

author: LAPhill
content:
For a bit of perspective: One of the top articles on CNN was about an AI generated image of the pope and how we’re headed into dangerous times when we’re flooded by images and can’t tell real from fake. I remember being 10 years old at the barbershop (RIP when I had hair and went to a barber) and reading about this dangerous “Photoshop” technology that would make it hard to tell what was real. 

AI offers incredible breakthroughs, things we can’t fathom, but this ain’t the first time things have been disrupted.

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm still formulating my thoughts, but my initial impression was that it felt more lifeless than I expected. Watching it spit out words one by one, felt like I was having a conversation with a dial up modem. Really, it felt like a more intuitive search engine, and less like it was feeding me anything I couldn't attain in other ways (through more effort).

I asked it some questions about where to find information about programming languages and it turned up some helpful resources. I spent awhile asking it to code some things for me and it did so impressively, while leaving bits in the code that explained what it was doing. I can see that being massively useful for bug-hunting, but also as a learning tool. I was fascinated when I asked it to code me a GUI for this fake program and it complied. But when I asked it to show me what that would actually look like, it linked to an IMGUR image that didn't exist.

If I walked away with one feeling, it was curiosity, instead of anything negative.

author: spectrummasters
content: @Deleted User  and @masteredbyjack ....thanks for your perspectives gents. I dont disagree with you that what you are both describing is true for where we are at currently and have been for some time. im trying (badly) to not promote my view as opposed to the views shared by the engineers in the discussion im referencing....but fwiw , in 2022 the global recording revenue i think was around 20 billion dollars. Thats a lot of dough. Im not a socialist....im not against the free market.......the discussion was centred around the growing leverage engineers have in the industry and whether that is being marketed effectively to increase the price of the skilled labour engineers provide. When i first started getting indie production deals i was adviesd in the music business, when it comes to discussing deals, everyone's friends...when it comes to paying on those deals......no-one's friends....its only business. I have found this to be true and have no objection to it.

author: Deleted User
content:
how our clients come up with money to pay us is important in order to stay sustainable. because we’re technically in a business of helping another business (artists or labels) make money. 

huge part of our values are tied to our ability to make them money. so of course it matters. 

And our ability to make them money isn’t directly parallel to how good we are at what we do. If they made money, it’s probably because everyone in the team nailed it. But if it’s not making money- that’s not because we sucked at our job. 

Which is why I started getting more involved in artist branding, I wish I could offer enough insights in building a fan base and marketing side of things. Because then I can really be more in control of the situation. 

but even then- there’s not enough money in the market. there’s a long and steep valley of despair between climbing from bottom to top. I do think if there was more money in the pool, the valley of despair wouldn’t be that bad. and in order to pull more money in, crowdfunding could be one of the ways. I wish I can come up with more solutions…

author: LAPhill
content:
Think about what it means to a client when you say you're going to miss a deadline because of someone else's project. Now they feel like they're not important enough to be worth your time, so why work with you? You might get away with that for a little while with low level indie artists, but you better believe a label or artist with a busy schedule, tour dates, social media promo, etc., is not going to deal with that.

I sympathize with the overbooking - it happens to anyone that's climbing the ladder, trying to take on good work and level up, but you've got to find a way to solve it without making it the client's problem. Get help, don't sleep, whatever you need to do.

author: Will Melones
content:
I guess it depends heavily on scale. $40 a month just to keep the doors open sounds steep for an artist who isn't already selling merch at a consistent rate. I haven't looked at Shopify's print on demand pricing, but in general POD is much higher cost than bulk screen printing t-shirts (for example). So if you're a band selling at the scale where $40/mo. on a slow month isn't your *entire* profit margin, it seems like investing in a run of merch would pay for itself.

Now this is completely different if you look at it from the perspective of a clothing brand, where the goal is to have a diversity of designs available at all times, without the need for warehousing and a huge startup cost, and to consistently push sales to a customer base that's devoted to *the merch*. I can't imagine the vast majority of DistroKid artists are going that hard on ecommerce, but they could sure benefit from having their POD merch visible on their Spotify profile. The small artists I work with would probably be better off putting $40 into Instagram ads every month.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Why?   Because "pop rock" is a trendy commodity. As that generation leaves the market (for pop its 12-25), they have some nostalgia value for the aging generation, but after that?...  very little market value. Rod Stewart is a perfect example.  His music (and personal brand) is not timeless. They will be luck to recoup $100 Million from this purchase.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
That's the thing...  I think the earnings of 20th century recordings are going to diminish as the generations die.  Currently catalogs from popular music of the 1940s and 50s...  this peer group is almost extinct.  In 20yrs those catalogs will not have a multiple value, but it will be a diminished return (less than 1x) ....  not a growth (greater than 1x multiple).  

If Rod Stewarts catalog generated $300 Million during the height of his popularity (including tours)...   The value of his catalog over the decades would be a fraction of that.  To recoup $100 Million would require $10 Million x 10yrs in ROYALTY alone to break even. He (reportedly) earned $7 Million from his music in 2013.  So the ROI couldn't profit until 2037 (without touring income).  His fanbase will be effectively extinct by 2040 and it's going to be hard to break 1980s trends on future generations.  You'll get some novelty bumps but I don't know how many Kate Bush moments investors can bank on.  Seems more lottery and less solid investment

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Nah.  It's a core function of capitalist economics.  Without counter-weights,  the theoritical end game of all markets is a single provider of all services. That's what the board game tries to illustrate.  Specialization is only valuable for individuals.  Corporations (especially those with shareholders) must continuously grow and expand profit centers.  It's why Amazon doesn't just sell books anymore...  and grocery stores start pushing their private label brands...  or fast food chains earn more from real estate than from selling food.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
This video brought to mind a highlight from a recent read: "When you’re invested in a goal, being doubted by experts is a threat. They may be credible, but since they don’t recognize your potential, they’re not coaches who will help you improve. Their disbelief quickly becomes your insecurity. It shatters your confidence and stifles your growth. That’s a self-fulfilling prophecy. But the research suggests that when they come from an uninformed audience, low expectations can become a self-negating prophecy. You’re motivated to shatter their confidence that you won’t succeed. Samir calls it the underdog effect." - Adam Grant, *Hidden Potential*

Also related are the concepts of the Pygmalion and the Golem effect in social psychology. Where low / high expectations for students / beginners can become self fulfilling prophecies. Begs the question how do you find the balance between being honest / truthful with folks just starting out without significantly undermining their intrinsic motivation and confidence?

author: Rukie
content:
the word “emotion” needs a better definition sometimes in the space we are in. 

Emotion isn’t necessarily something that you are always aware of “feeling”. Some reactions are merely state of mind, until it is given a name. Some reactions are visceral because of what the chemicals do to our body. 
sometimes, it’s neither visceral nor label-able. Which makes us assume that it’s not a feeling or emotion. But can we really differentiate emotions and thoughts? What exactly would differentiate them? 

On the other hand, there is music that pushes more, versus music that pulls more. 

Just like how audio is bipolar, we can’t have connections just be a one way communication. Tame Impala is a type of music that pulls. You don’t know why, but you just want to know “what was that song? I GOTS TO FIND OUT”. 

Push is more like… “I can’t unhear it” a lot of Pop hits are push with some pull factor. 

the ones that make you bummed out that you couldn’t shazam are ones that pull you in. it’s a slight push that gets you listening, and the rest of it is just pulling you in. (my own reaction when I first heard tame impala and couldn’t find out whose song it was)

Culturally, I think the love for (dreamy sound) can be explained with a desire to escape reality. 

So really, the emotional reaction is that “it transports me into a different space”. My theory on “why do people like that feeling?” is that many people aren’t happy with the reality of our lives because of economy and what not. And the idea of “escape from reality” became more and more a viable thing for us to want after experiencing digital devices and internet.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I was recently inspired after going to the cinema to see *A Complete Unkown*, the movie memoir about Bob Dylan; partially by Bob's story, but also by Timothy Chalomee's performance as Bob. All of the shots of him performing in the movie were fully live - which is an impressive feat by itself - but even more impressive that he apparently wasn't much of a musician before making the movie. I didnt know much about Timothy before this, so I watched his interview with Zane Lowe on Apple Music's YouTube channel. One thing I found really interesting was how available he made himself to learning the role. For example, he didn't turn his phone on for 3 months straight. Got me thinking about how much I can get distracted during the day, and how these distractions can get in the way of me actually giving 100% to the art that I'm working on. I'm sure you all can imagine how the distractions in your own life can effect your work. Might be TikTok videos, might be discord, might be lusting over getting new converters or monitors or guitars, etc, you get the idea. So I guess what I'm saying here is that if I want to compete with the best, maybe I have to understand how to impliment systems in my life that allows me to be more available to the things that I am working on. I want it to be like lifiting a heavy weight at the gym - at the bottom of a heavy squat, you've no choice but to focus on pushing the bar back up with good form, cos that think will break you otherwise. There's a certain thing that happens in your brain when you're forced to only think about one thing for a prolonged, or even short period. It's something akin to meditating. 

I guess what I'm asking is if anyone has ever given this subject any thought before, and if anyone has ever done anything to get better at these things? I'm still not sure if all this only makes sense inside my own head.

author: Zach Hughes
content: It's so strange. Part of me wonders if the role of the artist is increasingly subsumed by entertaining and engaging on social media platforms, then will human artists be able to compete with always on AI content machines masquerading as artists? I don't want to normalize calling TaTa an artist. That honestly might be one of the more pernicious aspects of the Timbaland story.

author: spectrummasters
content: I feel that the more the business of music devalues the price of labour of the human musician , it will have a counterintuitive impact. The real musician becomes the rarity . I see AI and social media driving out fair weather “musical creators “ and leaving behind only those who do it cause they have to , not because they “can “ . So the less people can make a living out of making music the more I see music returning to the hands of true , passionate artists . When you can’t afford to do it …..but you can’t stop . That’s the art that’s important . I think we are moving there

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you zoom in on the yellow suit, every one of those images are composed of hand-sewn beads. And that's not even the most intricate example. If you zoom in on the purple suit that is an entire three-dimensional castle that hangs from the front. If you were able to peer inside the windows you would see curtains on the interior, and at the drawbridge, a small horse emerging. The attention to detail is off the charts.

The splendor is overpowering. It took me 90 minutes to make my way through everything. The deeper you look, the better it gets. It's awe inspiring stuff.

author: spectrummasters
content:
My impression is that it started with the British Invasion bands , firstly the Beatles …..coming to America and then not being able to hear themselves on stage for the actual hysterical screaming audiences . This created the need for massive levels of sound from the amps . Which the who then took to the ultimate extremes creating the “loudest band “ aesthetic , by which time heavy rock is the thing ….and heavy rock aint doing gentle . Then that sets the bar/expectation . 
Personally , more than the levels it’s the spectral balance for me . I’ve been amongst the sweetest tuned sound systems loud as fcuk and no discomfort or ringing ears whatsoever , and then go to a pub and a speaker by the bar rips my ears off cause it’s all mids .

author: Zack Hames
content:
I disagree, personally, about the reaching out part. 

I think there’s a lot of merit to positing what you’re up to if you’re a working musician / engineer. People hire busy people. It’s a weird thing. 

Also it’s a way for people to be reminded you exist. And I believe you can do it in an authentic and non frustrating way, as horrendous as social media can be.

author: Will Trotman
content:
Interesting, that’s good to hear it’s gotten better, I was assuming it had gone the other way. 

I just wonder what kind of disruption could be large enough to cause a shift away from Spotify, since they’re pretty firmly on top. It seems like streaming is about as easy as it’s going to get, and I don’t really hear any Spotify users with qualms about their experience.

I do wonder if artists will become less partial to Spotify over time though. It seems like there are so many different metrics of success now (Spotify streams, instagram followers, tik tok followers are the main ones I think of) that aren’t always mutually inclusive of each other. And I wonder if that takes a little weight off of streaming numbers being the only metric that legitimizes an artist. And I hear people like Ryan Tedder talk about the importance of “world building” for artists now - I wonder if fans of artists will care more about being part of that artist’s ecosystem than the artist’s music being a part of their music library. I think of how K Pop bands sell crazy numbers of physical copies as an example. They can still stream the music but it seems like there are more variables now.

Thinking out loud a little bit, I might have just said absolutely nothing with a lot of words lol.
